page.title: 01BISHOPS ITCHINGTON
page.content: {Bishops Itchington}- the town on the {River Itchen}- which up to the Dissolution belonged to the See of Lichfield, was given by{Leofric of {Mercia}to the newly-formed Priory of Coventry in 1O43. Enclosed by Fisher in 1547 and converted to sheep walks the village was deserted and demolished and only developed in the later nineteenth century when the arrival of the railway in 1851 made viable the exploitation of the local { {Blue Lias}stone for the manufacture of cement. The actual quarry is situated in the Harbury survey area; the workers' houses were built here, two miles away, and the village became a 'company town'. In the 195O's the { {Cement Works}closed - the remaining stone being of low quality - and Bishops Itchington was designated by the County Council as a 'growth
